TMobC-RYgcqos3CcfhaOog.text: A real institution in London, for me a place to go very early in the morning (or very late in the night) when out in London. It's open 24h a day and is always full of all sorts of people. Food is ok too, if you have lived in Italy this could be the local bar round the corner.

NZvVMo8XtyW4RZOWL1uKdw.text: This an authentic Italian cafe right in the heart of Soho, mirrored walls, seats indoors and outdoors, great coffees, cakes, sandwiches, lovely friendly staff open late! Great in the summer time, you can sit outside, sipping coffe and watching the world go by!

S6ztdwwKImdCLUfEKU65Sg.text: I love Bar Italia. In the summer you can sit outside and watch the world go by sipping a coffee and enjoying a panini or one of the excellent range of meals on offer.

U1kofLvnQhY4bt9j-ULx2Q.text: Bar Italia has great Cappuccino. The 60's theme is nice when relexing on lunch. The cookies are great as well. It's open late to as well not one of these other coffee shops that shut at 6 pm on the dot. The seats to sit down on are great and it better in the summer as you can sit outside and relex.

w868LnJB6nNhUvVqxw9zsQ.text: Bar Italia is a place to chill out with a group of friends. There are outdoor seating and it is good for having a cigar with a cup of tasty coffee. Sometimes they have cakes. Although I am not into cakes and sweets, my girlfriend also goes crazy when she orders them from the bar counter. According to her, the cappuccino is quite good and strong and she is a picky gal. I love the authentic atmosphere of the place and the relaxing air around it. Marvelous café! I think it serves food too; will like to try it someday.

nb8E1oGvO3QJNASBAJqkbQ.text: A must go to if you're in Soho. Great Italian coffee and nice pastries/cakes. There's a great atmosphere and a fantastic place to people spot/watch Soho life go by.

6qNOE3DAxr79Vtd2JU1OHQ.text: This place has 3 things going for it - coffee, sandwiches and live Italian football. Make a mix of those 3 and you'll have a good evening. But the idea that this is some florentine caffe straight out of Italy is misguided. YOu can sit on the street admiring the passers by here like you can in Italy and nor should you try to because the prices are far too high. Coffees are over 3 quid and if you want anything sweet youre much better off going to Maison Bertaux down the road. Im not really sure this place can offer an Italianophile a great deal unless the Azurri are playing.

5oody-SnLQFuf1K-wlTypg.text: Park your Vespa outside any hour of the day or night and run in to grab an espresso at the bar. Alternatively sit outside in the summer (if you can get a table) - it's a great spot to people watch. Bar Italia is located just off Old Compton Street, in the heart of Soho, and it's a real West End institution. Forget the Red Bull and get a coffee here before an evening of clubbing or come here after eating at a restaurant or after the theatre. Bar Italia is always full of interesting characters: it's gay-friendly but not gay-dominated, and there's buckets of somewhat cheesey Italian charm.

hY9ekiJ0OzNgl7KLSgtNpw.text: One of the few 24-hour places in London, it offers, simply, the best cappuccino in town. The decor feels really authentic and they show italian football matches! But the nicest thing to do is to sit outside, even in winter, as they have heaters, and watch the mixed and particularly interesting Soho crowd.

78LHUGGNXL6WmPHLIWUApA.text: There are many coffee bars in London, here you feel like you are in Italy. Apart from the usual coffee's there are plenty sandwiches and cakes to choose from too. It has that 60's feel about it, great for nostalgia seekers. Ideal stop off either before or after theatre visits.

bVehQzBDJjzbKgns8xESTA.text: Great little place to stop for a coffee and a sandwich. Wonderful cappuccino, tasty sandwiches, and pleasant service. I'm not sure why everyone is complaining about the prices: no, it's not the cheapest place on the block, but it's reasonable considering the location and the quality.

cLojKcvR_4tJzfejw9AIfA.text: this place is a London institution. its been around since the 60's, and likely has been a meeting and pickup hub ever since. you can grab a decent Euro coffee here (not as rare now in London as back in the day), and plan an evening of derring do and dastardly deeding, or contemplate some Foucault or Derrida over your long shot (i mean the coffee, not your unpublished script).

AeRfEtylqyIVs-cF_SR6aQ.text: Legendary SoHo hangout. One of the only remaining old haunts. Had a sensitive refit a few years back which kept the place as it was, but still in one piece. Still find it amazing that so many people who say they know London have never been there for a coffee at 3 in the morning!

93z5trgJhzjbJd62QrwBAA.text: Legendary. The place where I'm almost guaranteed to end up in on a night out in Soho. Bar Italia is open 24 hours and you can head for a strong, sobering coffee at any time. You get a real mix of people here, true Italians, gay men and women, tourists, those who have heard the song by Pulp and want to experience it first hand etc. I've heard that Miss Moss is seen here a bit but cannot say if it's true as I've never seen her there. Oh, and the food is OK if you a) have enough cash left at the end of the night (it's a bit pricey for what it is) and b) can eat after alcohol consumption.

IArtCtVcBRIDUBJJkOlsNg.text: A great place to catch a coffee and a slice, whiile watching the people of the world. Soho was made for a place like this and this place was made for Soho. The quaint mix of charm and cheese make this place a must visit in London.

bT7y2kjhHvqB6QRYmXDzgQ.text: Good to grab a quick, cheapish bite to eat before hitting Soho proper. Or good to grab something a bit more upmarket than a kebab on the way home. Not somewhere to stay and eat, I wouldn't say.

-Ov6SL6ZaJjlsTuDZorblg.text: this is the place to go before or after a night out.open 24 hours what better place to catch up.grab a drink ,bite to eat or chat all in one place.most people have heard of it but very few people have actually been.so if your one of them give it a go

7fZgocWYHPQyJLYPFfmHJg.text: This is the spot my boyfriend I go to when we are in the West End and want a coffee!  I love this place and if you can get an outdoor table in the summer it's ever better.  On hot days you can sit and people watch.  I have seen lots of funny things sitting at Bar Italia!  In addition to the great coffees they have delicious desserts as well.  I'm a little partial to their apple pie, it's more like a tart to me.  But the apples taste so fresh I am positive they make the cakes in first thing in the morning.  I love this spot!

vHIQ0WltsgQFEeMWnsaA9Q.text: The guys at Bar Italia are great. They make excellent coffee, the ciabattas are to die for, and yes the connoli is lush. It is a great little cafe that has a homely, community vibe that always makes you feel welcome.My recomendation is to go down when the World or European Cup in football is on. Luca and the boys love there football. The passion and noise can be heard from down the street when Italy plays.

FWk1HpeUkmjCDJH-BZ4OYg.text: I came here to meet a friend who practically lives here. They had never been to Rays Jazz Cafe in Foyles, I'd never been here. Shocking, no? So we rectified this sharpish with a trip to both in one evening. And I like it here. But I don't really see what all the fuss is about. Friendly staff? Check? Old fashioned decor? Check? Nice atmosphere? Check. Everything about this place is great. It's just not singing out to me. I don't care that famous people come here to drink their coffee. For everyone else, i imagine this a five star venue, but for me, they're missing that extra something that will keep me going back time and time again. I just don't know what that something is, as they're doing everything right. Am I being fussy today?

zOlJrvc5w5AdMtYGIQo6Jw.text: It's definitely the perfect place when you're in the West End, you just got out of a club and you're looking for a place to grab something. It's funny how, after a certain quantity of beer or cocktails, your stomach reminds you it's craving for food, even if it's already 3 in the morning. I was with my friend Piotr who already knew this Italian bar when I just heard about it. It was indeed 3 in the morning when we got there. It was packed with a big night crowd smiling and chatting and trying to order something from the Italian staff joking with them. A great atmosphere! There's a television at the end to watch soccer or the Oscar ceremony. We got some sandwiches with coppa and a coke. It was heaven.

BM7cQfY0UBbY47lreaHxvw.text: I feel a bit mean giving such a landmark a low score, but of late I feel it's justified. Bar Italia does have some wonderful perks, it's in a great location and it's a great late night venue. What I don't get on with are the prices, or more, the ever changing prices. I am convinced that 5 lattes shouldn't cost £25! It felt like pocket rape. Another friend of mine also said they felt ripped off by the place. Like all tourist attractions, they love ramping up the prices and I feel Bar Italia is doing that. It is a shame, given that the place is full of legend and the coffee is beautiful. If they stop playing with prices I will happily go there more often. But at present I only go there when it's the early hours and I am desperate for a latte.

XOroo6S-NsPyHPoo7yCVCQ.text: The closest thing soho has still got to an institution. Since 1923 Bar Italia has seen just about everyone and everything pass through its doors. Famously a late-night haunt for people out in the west end who want a late bite to eat or a caffeine kick to keep them going even later, Bar Italia has seen it all and decided the best policy is to do what's been doing for years and years: serve good coffee, cakes and light bites at (fairly) reasonable prices. Tourists, local drunks, regulars, foreign students and londoners all flock here in droves to soak up the history or sit outside and people watch (probably the funnest place in london for this 21st century sport). To add to the atmosphere the staff are usually charmingly rude and speak in over-the-top italian-cockney accents. This is about as traditional as london gets so enjoy it whilst you can.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom

1dXyEmxz-syAtpQ5EXV1Fw.text: Have you ever been stranded at 4am in Soho? You've got 15 mates on your back, collectively chiming "you're the native Londoner, what are we gonna do now, it's bloody freezing!" You count on one hand the options that don't involve nudity, lecherous men or 20 quid pints and resolve you have two options. First up, you've got Balans on Wardour Street renowned for its queer door policy, overpriced food and snooty staff. Or you have cheap, cheerful and colourful Bar Italia, one of Soho's archetypical Italian institutions, delighting sober and less-than-sober punters since 1949. But hey, don't ask me, let's rope in my favourite anecdotal Britpoppers once more for a more musical exposé!Video link: uk.youtube.com/watch?v=l…

8QIfyWsqc4VoRZ2Hdpc5lw.text: This an authentic Italian cafe right in the heart of Soho, mirrored walls, seats indoors and outdoors, great coffees, cakes, sandwiches, lovely friendly staff. It's open late which is nice when you are out in the centre and just want a coffee and a chat with a friend before making the journey home.It's great in the summer time as you can sit outside, sipping coffee and watching the world go by.

oXJ6dXhvezayFH_M1p1GWw.text: bar Italia is wonderful and terrible. during the day it can be bustling with people and life. as previously stated, im not a coffee drinker, but they make a mean hot chocolate, and their paninis are massive. like wow. you can split one with a  friend and be totally fine. at night its a bit of a different world, but still their quality comes through. and at 3am, what would you rather eat, junk food like KFC? or a more or less fresh Panini from Bar Italia that at least tastes pretty amazing and is full of personality. my favorite thing is to sit in the window, day or night, and people watch.

vbir21cVMHl3RpDdSFZOkQ.text: A great Italian coffee bar in the centre of Soho. I've only been a few times after a late night in central London and it certainly is a great way to round off the evening. If you are lucky you will be able to grab a seat outside and watch the night life go by. Not sure if it is possible to get anything substantial to eat there, but for me it's more about the experience and Bar Italia can certainly provide that.

IXN1a1PFkF9DMDLObJPrJQ.text: I was first taken here on a date when Italy were playing in the World Cup a few years ago and the place was rammed. I thought this was a one off but really, this place is so popular and such an institution that it is always full of interesting, lively people. Coffees here are the best of the best in London - ignore those nearby coffee chains and come here for a REAL coffee! There are lots of other things to drink here - the Peroni is always flowing and there are lots of other Italian drinks to quaff. Food is good - ranging from great sarnies to cakes. This is a great place to bring friends who are new to London and want to people watch!

a6AfPbb-jmOwynrpRmm1Zw.text: Arguably the best place for a late night coffee and snack at the end of a night out in Soho. It has wonderful coffee and delicious pizzas. Often has lots of people showing off their motorcycles outside too if you're into that kind of thing. It's an amusing distraction when you're winding down after a night out on the tiles.

-XMe__jbOR5yFTYZB8hmNg.text: Italy in soho that what I can about this little place it's @ a good location seating inside & out side which I love it, coffee are brilliant, we go here at the time of European night of football gr8 atmosphere this boys love there football as they love there bar Italia service very good & helpful if you are in soho you should visit this lovely place.

dLJsvw5l5TlQfEJ9_s_4rQ.text: Where do you go for a late, late brunch after you've enjoyed too much in London?You know how it is after a night filled with alcohol and stuff, you wake up craving for real breakfast, excellent coffee, great sandwiches, good place and perhaps good crowd? All of the above, I've found in Bar Italia. Location wise, it is right at the heart of action and you know Soho, don't you! Love the fact that there are tables outside which looked pretty cozy for just savoring your food and downing your drinks and at the same time, the interiors looked warm and inviting. It felt like my resident bar/coffee shop even if it was just my first time to go. True to the establishment name itself, Italy was spelled all over the place, The flags, the logos, heck even the famous celebs, are all about Italia and are naturally found all over the place. There's a huge LCD screen mounted for the TV aficionados, which I guess comes pretty handy during the must-not-miss huge sporting events. I ordered myself their special Italy hot chocolate, one of the best I've tried in the world and their specialty, tuna-tomato-cheese sandwich, which came in 4 small sandwiches. What can I say but divine!So here's raising a glass to Bar Italia and the many more visits that I'd be making, this time won't be for brunch for sure! ;)

BH8tabhUXyA_kp_6JYREUg.text: If you ask a Londoner Where is the Heart of London? he will tell you Bar Italia. One of Sohos most successful and longest running cafes.The food is great however at a price tag of £6 for a pannini they should be.A single espresso is going for £2.If you just looking for a bite to eat go around the corner on Greek street for cafe Valentino which is very cheap and just as good.

7pAQOnoPBb_G-fImuFDuUw.text: The only place to end up in Soho when you know you shouldn't drink anymore but you are not ready to go home yet. It's 3am so line up with the other drunk revellers, order an overpriced toasted panini (like £8!) and eat half of it while talking to other random people. Then it's time to stumble off to the mini cab round the corner and get totally ripped off again.

rmfOQc35zNjhhMyqe-LFRw.text: For once in my life not wanting a beer I popped into Bar Italia for the first time two weeks ago and was pleasantly surprised by its authenticity. I'm pretty used to being disappointed by ethnically oriented cafes and eateries and especially so in such tourist-oriented districts as Soho, but I found Bar Italia to be the real thing. I actually heard Italian being spoken. I do find the prices obscene, but then this is Soho, and though I could have had two pints at the Red Lion for what I paid for a single coffee at Bar Italia, I still stand by this place. Highly endorsed.

d8XKm78xJy2BA-WkvlPh5g.text: Bar Italia is open 24 hours.the best place for a late night,the best espresso in London....

R0FfvxqiUczt_uUfNvmVxQ.text: While the name is a bit blatant, I have yet to find a spot in London that feels so much like a local Italian cafe.  There's the brusque but charming service, the hordes of vespa drivers (there is actually a Bar Italia Scooter Club that holds Sunday meetings here), the Italian football on TV, the amazing coffees and cappucinos... The food is OK, but I find it best after a hard night out.  Their simple ham and cheese panini hits the spot.

jsNSlPTR8iHl6APyLHGJuA.text: An insomniac's best friend. This Soho standby is the perfect place (and the only place) to end a late night out or to run off to at 3am when you can't sleep and just want to leave the house. A bit on the pricey side and probably not the best latte in town, but as one of the few places actually open after midnight in London it's probably the best latte you'll get in the small hours. And thanks to the smoking ban, staying indoors is a bit more tolerable without the cloud of cigarette smoke hanging around your head. Be prepared for massive crowds at just about any time of day. That being said, its the sot of place you have to go at least once to form your own love/hate opinion of.

A1_0EF98wIsNkUxzX4rFSQ.text: I'm going against the grain as this place has never had a review lower that 4 stars, so my two stars may be quite a slur. I feel quite justified though in giving Bar Italia a low mark and interestingly, people largely seem to visit here in the daytime, my experience comes from a nocturnal visit.We (the 6 people I went with) arrived there at around 11pm-ish and it was already busy and soon enough it got busier still, a lot of people for a relatively small place. It was at this point which one of our group left for the reason that Bar Italia was "shit"!The "shit" conclusion was reached for the reason that not only was it too crowded (that's not why I disliked the place) but there wasn't a comprehensive choice for drinks -  they have no beer taps, only bottled lager and spirits which isn't good for a late night club/bar and these cost more than a pint despite getting less liquid wonderment than in a pint.Also, the place was ridiculously warm (ridiculously warm! I wasn't the only one who felt the need to pop outside at intervals for 5 minutes a time to cool down) and with not much room to move within the establishment this did make the inside a humid place. Then there was the crap music (my personal view) and the bouncers who felt the need to assert themselves with meaningful stares and just a busy attitude. They should've relished the opportunity to take it easy as their wasn't a sign of trouble but the Men in Black needed to remind you that it was them in charge and there would be NO MISBEHAVING FOO! Unnecessarily cautious.It's £5 to enter and that isn't the most expensive entry fee in the area but when there are so many other late night bars/clubs in the vicinity I don't think I'll be going back.Ciao, Ian

8NBdy0MFbCCK6QIqPC7cRw.text: Espresso like any other burned one in London...PLUS priced at 2,50 Pounds, absolutely not worth!Just another clichée for italian tourists

iiwzIQ0luL6PtEoF0pgqfg.text: This small slice of Napoli or New York's Little Italy, has been a real institution in Soho for decades. More cafe with paninni bar and drinks served on the side, prosciutto hams hanging from the ceiling along with Italian flags and photographs of famous Italians on the walls. it does have a very nostalgic feel to it, which adds to its charm. Excellent, real Italian espresso, need I say more. Though I will say, the most expensive cup of coffee in the city.

-7A1SRlq2po0oh_C8OGL2g.text: I love this little place! It is open until the early morning hours, and just the right place to stop by for a filling sandwich, creamy Italian dessert or simply a drink, especially after a night out on the town! The place is always bustling with all sorts of interesting clientele who pop in, just like everyone else who does, to enjoy the thriving atmosphere this joint has to offer. I like to sit on the seats just outside right by Frith street, to simply enjoy a spot of people watching, as you just never get bored!Sat under the outside heaters provided, I like sipping on their hot  chocolate, which is thick and creamy, as you would expect a good Italian hot chocolate to taste. They also have my favourite liqueur, Limoncello, which I occasionally enjoy having, and also packs a strong punch, but really does warm you up. Bar Italia has been around for sometime now, since 1949, and is still a constantly thriving, popular place to go to.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom

ofRvZUH99vdd2dxY9aNqmQ.text: Nice bar on a street corner in Soho where you can sit on a pavement seat and watch a colourful parade of characters walk past.I'm awarding 4 stars for pretty good milkshakes made with real Italian ice cream. Nice and thick with good flavour and perfect on a hot day

bqyZvkZVRHQM5DeEQrIqYQ.text: Bar Italia is a tad pricey. A small cappuccino and a large latte came up to more than £7. I'm fairly certain that it should have been less than £6 in most independent coffee shops, but I guess that's the price you pay for partaking of coffee in one of Soho's most established institutions. Cost aside, Bar Italia's a great place for people-watching and, more importantly, watching football games, especially if Italy happen to be playing. It's open 24 hours and is one of those places you can adjourn to after a long night out without being harassed. I've never been here for an alcoholic drink, but those coming here late at night should note the 'Bar' in 'Bar Italia' means a European bar, as opposed to an English bar, so no alcohol is served after 11 pm.

4StRtqGRftCmfthzdnPyYg.text: Bar Italia was a lovely spot to pass a mild London evening. My companions sipped espressos while I had a hot chocolate at a table on the sidewalk out front. We spotted numerous drag queens while perched there and were even approached by one who invited us to a show that night (a shame we couldn't take her up on it!)

NCbMZwz8kUng8RtR47ayqw.text: Always great coffee and friendly service. Does need a lick of paint though as looking a little tired rather than vintage

zwTnIDvPIKL7cRRvz0rJVw.text: Lovely retro coffee bar with faded interior which has not been updated for years apart from a flatscreen LCD tv... It maybe very retro but it's baristas are cute Italian men...Anyway the latte was pretty decent but I opted to skip the wide range of cakes, paninis and biscuits as I was wasting time before lunch. Nonetheless the place was busy with a young vibrant crowd. Instead of opting for a starbucks coffee, support this coffee bar so it continues to serve another generation of londoners and tourists.

lZnRPKmKMVVWFOa3PGGMtg.text: Authentic Italian bar.  If you know Italian you can certainly practice it here. Insanely delicious panini.

1q9oH4FSTTebMpeHgmkWFA.text: Although Bar Italia is situated on what is probably one of the most touristy streets in London, I love the place.  There is nothing more fun than people watching (and playing fashion police/ the Tourist vs. Local Game at times) while enjoying an espresso.  I love that all of the staff are Italian as well, they are always so friendly.I think my fondest memory of Bar Italia was during the World Cup 2006.  I had to watch the game here, I just had to.  The party started as soon as I woke up.  I will never forget being crammed in the bar (worse than the subway during rush hour) and standing on a bar stool to view the game since I'm so short.  Except for 2 very drunk France fans, the entire bar had some sort of blue shirt on, had tricolor face paint, and sang and shouted profanities in Italian...simply amazing.  Anyhow, I'm still up there on the bar stool, swaggering around because I've been drinking for 7 hours at this point.  Fast forward to the epic Zidane headbutt: one of the French drunkards kicked the bar stool out from under me.  I think I saw my life flash before my eyes.  I'm pretty sure I'm a masochist because I consider this to be one of the most fun experiences of my life.  This cute Italian couple caught me.  I lived to tell the tale AND the bartender got me another Stella!

1zGRgZlbc8nVG8Gx1yDQ-w.text: For a coffee shop it's blooming expensive... no two ways of looking at it. Over £3 for a double macchiato is punchy wherever you are. that being said, it's a Soho institution and there are a number of people who will remember whiling away an evening round the old pinball machine upstairs.

mgveNVymZh3WMKa5q_p3Cw.text: Stepping into Bar Italia is like being transported to mainland Europe.  All the staff and customers seem to be Italian, which is weird, for such a touristy street.  So, it is awesome that it is there.What is super awesome about this place is that it never seems to close.  Even after the last of the late night bars has shut, Bar Italia still has their door open.  I'm not sure I've ever seen it shut, actually.  One of my favorite sandwiches in the entire world is their chicken escalope.  It is amazing.  Get ONE and split with a friend.  You WILL be full.  Do not be a greedy piggy and eat the whole thing and get a stomach ache like some piggies I know.  (i.e. me.)And naturally the coffee and cakes and pastries are all excellent.  Again, more like Italy than England.Only reason I'm giving 4 stars and not 5 is that the staff isn't super friendly, and the inside doesn't have particularly comfortable seating.  That's why I use it mainly as a late night takeaway spot.  But will continue to do so until they close their doors, which I hope will be never.

zWF3wSCFecXdRc8qPxHm7w.text: Caffeine, people watching, football watching.  It's all good.It's been three years since I was here, yet I still hear the Pulp lyrics in my head"You can't go home and go to bed,because it hasn't worn off yet,and now it's morning.There's only one place we can go.It's around the corner in Soho,where other broken people go.Let's go. "

NdUgwEUd8nDgaffSBunrUA.text: What wins for bar italia is the atmosphere. Great place for people watching. Crazy busy. Its worth it to sit outside though.There's better coffee in London, but not at night. I'm a fan of their tiramisu, although my friends prefer the other cakes.

3rJLHS2hpHDndhzWxbe1cg.text: Bar Italia is a Soho institution as well as the inspiration for a Pulp song ( uk.youtube.com/watch?v=z… ). Many people swear by the coffee there, which is good, but I prefer Monmouth. They also sell paninis which are good but overpriced, as perhaps is the coffee. Still to complain about the price would be to miss the point somewhat. It is one of the few places in London that always seems to be open. Often you find yourself there unintentionally after a night out sitting on a table or the curb amongst other people in a similar state of disrepair trying to engage in some debate or another. Also, last year I went and shook hands with Tim Westwood.Unsurprisingly, it also acts as something of a centre for the Italian community and is good fun whenever there's an Italian sporting event on.

1xcTfpWgCwfjQPch44JbXQ.text: 60's themed decor, legendary, old time haunt, open long hours and an institution in Soho. All of this is true of this fiercely Italian joint where you can still catch a strong cuppa at 3 in the morning. It isn't cheap (quite pricey in fact) and the staff do have a brusque sort of italian male thing going on but you do get to people-watch and may even see someone rather famous come in for their fix.

EMOtSgrXTy9kI8ISsRKYaQ.text: Bar Italia is la great place, ta taste of Italy, the best coffee around, great service and a fun atmosphere.

H2t-rJcwXowkFc05viJf3Q.text: Hands down the best cafe in all of London for people watching. Smack dab in the middle of Soho, where a rainbow of people congregate, is this old coffee shop that probably hasn't changed or updated its authentic Italian look since it first opened.  I have been coming here for the last 6 years of my London life, and find that it is still the one place I can count on for social amusement. However, when it is football time, stay clear! This place gets packed to the max with avid viewers! The oddly enough non-Italian staff are very friendly and humorous. The espresso and cappuccinos are quite tasty and strong, though not exactly the real deal you get in Napoli itself.  @ £2.00 for an espresso and £2.80 for a cappuccino, we can agree that it is overpriced, as are most drinks in central London. In the winter they also make a fabulous hot chocolate! If you fancy desert, then the tiramisu is highly recommended! Best to come here in small numbers as there usually aren't enough seats to accommodate large groups.

2qPCOVt_guuogOtwI3WSMg.text: Whether it's a morning Latte and a pastry or a drunken late night panino, this is the best coffee shop in the world. Great vibe and superb coffee. I Love Bar Italia.

WZ4QZS3cWvZywKwyh6FmMA.text: A friend of mine was recommended this place for having the best cappuccinos. We sat outside the cafe at a table, very lovely. The cappuccino was lovely along with the ambiance. If you are not a coffee person they have very nice freshly squashed juices. You can taste the bits of fruit they had freshly squeezed in to make it. We tried the carrot and pear smoothies, both great just depends on if your wanting something sweet or savory. Had such an unexpected wonderful time we even met Mark Freeman. He was sitting at the table beside us enjoying a cappuccino as well, goes to show the place is great !

qJ6QXHCaZweCfT7QO-3bGg.text: The food looks delicious, but the waiters are the worst. The amount of sass that they convey is unacceptable and uncalled for.

BHTQAhSETgHBhg0RQYIThg.text: I can't believe I haven't reviewed Bar Italia before - I've been coming here late at night for years and it's been consistently fantastic.You know those nights when you know you've had your fill of alcohol, but you really don't want the fun to end? Go to Bar Italia.The nights after you've been to the Curzon and you don't want booze, you just want good coffee? Go to Bar Italia.Those times that you feel that the most effective use of your time would be to sit outside and people-watch? Go to Bar Italia. (Seriously - Old Compton and the surrounding streets see their fair share of sights, and so should you).I can't vouch for what it's like during the day, but I know that once you've spent an hour sitting outside here at 2am, you'll never forget it.

H2yR3y0bhe_nx_DCrMrg7Q.text: Arriving at London after a 3 italian city trip, we needed to find a place that served a proper italian cappucino. After watching the layover with bourdain and saw that this place was Anthony Bourdain approved, decided to take a shot. The cappucino at this place definitely comparable to what we had in Italy, even down to the grazie

UxaUh8JryakxaWE6PNyF7Q.text: This place has history, not super clean or new but they made a pretty good double espresso macchiato, they have some bar stools inside to encourage you to drink up your drink and move on with your day.  They serve a variety of food as well, I didn't get a chance to try it, but they open early and close late.

NPuZcnN-xpWi2JkMHnXdPQ.text: "It's around the corner in Soho where other broken people go. Let's go."       Pulp brought me here..  along with the service, coffee and cannoli's...Growing up with true Italian neighbours, I know what cannoli's and coffee should taste like.. stop in any hour, any day and you won't be disappointed.And for history buff's not familiar with the area..Logie Baird first demonstrated television in a laboratory above the Bar Italia café

XUkXono5-DNtzC5yRZnboA.text: Sit here on a sunny day. Drink one of the best coffees in soho. Enjoy just as good pastries and food. Engage in a long session of conversation about your love life (or lack thereof) and finally spend hours talking about strangers passing by.Love it.

UbNjEBGhiRUe7ZLXZyu0nA.text: Quite simply, the best cappuccino in town. Other than that, Bar Italia is a great location for people watching, relaxing in the afternoon, watching a football match or to take a coffee break on a night out in Soho.Food & drink are not cheap, but that's to be expected in the location. Quality and atmosphere more than make up for this.

U4zRpU7TxtwqIfPKSOIhYA.text: Though other reviews discuss the cafe, I went at 1am and this was an energy filled dance club upstairs. The dynamic of dancing to live life well, (rather than as a means to a random hookup) drink champagne and interact with everyone was refreshing. Go here to dance and believe in humanity!

Vo6sCl58J4eOftCxyRL6Mw.text: This is where Italians - passionate for their sport -go to watch matches : its impossible to get anyseat at World Cup, so what will happen whenwe host the Olympic Games, who knows.....itsgreat for the ebullient atmosphere & lovely coffee.In this building- upstairs- in 1924 the scottish scientist & inventor,John Logie Baird, occupied two attic rooms& on 26th January, demonstrated television before 50scientists. A year later, he transmitted a signal through480 miles of telephone line between London & Glasgow.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Royal Wedding Day

EIz_azevHDf6U47ioYB36Q.text: This is a pretty cosy place that opens up 'til late hours. I pass by every once in a while after dinner and they make the best cappuccino. We asked them for something that wasn't on the menu and they were so kind to make it for us.

DQhhYwTPd2b-GNAhx9a7vg.text: When I first traveled to Europe (and yes, England, you are part of Europe whether you like it or not), I asked a simple question: where can I get the best cup of coffee.After all, I'd seen Hudson Hawk so I know what can happen as one tries to find a caffeine fix. This place didn't disappoint. The coffee is great and there are several small televisions that play either: some euro-sport or (on good days) really bad euro-music video shows.The staff is great. Funny, but doing their own thing. You are there for their show. But no worries because they do make you feel right at home. If there's a seat outside, sit down. (Don't ask, Americans, just sit down.)But inside, it's cool and there's rarely a crowd.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom

IfYP51shjOeN_H2B89DwJg.text: Bar Italia is a Soho Sight if ever there was one.Lou and Caterina Polledri opened Bar Italia in 1949 and then their Son Nino took over the reins in the 1970s and he in turn handed over to his son's Antonio and Luigi and sister Veronica. The three of them run Bar Italia, the restaurant Little Italy next door. Another important part of Bar Italia is the large screen television which shows all the Italian sports. Bar Italia is the home of Italian football - so if in town during the World or European Cup get yourself down during a match.

S19Z0EBWUHRFESXdbwikXA.text: Late night people-watching mecca, right in the heart of Soho (London).Always busy and buzzing, serves a great coffee and has a wide range of foods to consider (late at night).  Staff are great, proces reasonable and they open pretty late, to say the least.

jy2dMpYgLBoRqGi_iUn1dA.text: This place was fine for a nice cup of coffee and to sit outside and people watch. Across from the place is a franchise coffee shop and boy was I happy to be at this place instead. The coffee is a bit gritty but yummy and the tables are worn down, but it had fun artwork on them. A nice little small place with tons of character.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Bagel sandwich
Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Latte heaven

SUmtaHDnHIDChoXyGkWeKw.text: Not necessarily the best value or in my view the best coffee  but nevertheless a Soho institution with plenty of buzz and character  especially given it's rather narrow dimensions.I'd suggest sitting outside late at night around the time the clubs close  you get a really fun mix of all kinds of people.Charming character and a vintage vibe.

l3s50ZoC99zWjuQ-nu2wAg.text: I wanted to love this place. I love, love, love Italy's bars, where you roll in, stand at the counter, order your espresso, pay your .80 Euro, brave minor burns on your hands from the ripping hot cup that has been sitting atop the espresso machine and minor burns in your throat from the boiling caffeinated bitterness that is legit Italian "caffe." Perhaps you exchange pleasantries with the barista. The entire process takes five minutes max - ideally around two minutes and afterward, you feel alive again. This occurs all day, every day from Alto Adige to Sicily - Italy may be a hot mess of regional political and cultural divisions, but damn it, the coffee ritual unites the place! But I digress.We staggered in around 11:30 pm after way too much delicious Sichuan food at Barshu a few doors down. On the surface, this could be a bar in Italy - old-man-but-now-trendy tipples like Fernet Branca behind the counter, big espresso machine. But not really. We rolled up to the counter. A server intercepted us and made us look at a menu (why?). She promptly went away, even though we were set to order. When I asked for espresso, she gave me the "Really?" look, as though I should be ordering some mug full of milky BS like the other patrons. At 11:30 pm. Yes, I really wanted an espresso, and the message was eventually received. When the coffee finally came, after about five minutes, which is a reasonable wait time in a normal British cafe but would be considered an eternity at a bar in Italy - it tasted pretty good. Not de-fanged and insufficiently bitter like espresso at chains like Costa or Caffe Nero. But the cup was cold and the entire experience left me feeling cold to Bar Italia, especially since a single espresso costs £2.60 and process took 15 minutes. That feels inherently un-Italian to me.Perhaps one needs to come here at 4 AM to understand the praises that Bar Italia's acolytes sing so loudly. Maybe I'll give it a try again sometime when out in Soho or in a fit insomnia/strange desire for a night bus adventure - yes, £2.60 is un-Italian for a coffee, but not the end of the world if it turns out to be a bad investment. Maybe the "element" in the wee hours does serve to justify this place's cult following. But my first visit left a bad taste.

it9Ay7OLTGX3uMRrDemWlQ.text: Hello Italy. Oh I'm sorry, is this Soho? I'm confused. Bar Italia is a slice of Rome in Soho. Café style coffee, service and seating, it's a perfect way to people watch.Don't believe me? Check out the leather skinned poser, long hair smuggling her waddle and the large shades disguising her crows feet sat next to you. Yes, she's a classy lady and the fag on her lip add to her cool...As for the coffee, fabulous! Bitter, smooth and strong, just the way I like to start my mornings.

2UKyWq8GLPX8hWrgZao7Hg.text: It's hard to separate the reputation and air of louche cool from what Bar Italia actually is - a good coffee shop with a strong identity in an excellent location. If you can grab a seat outside, do, even if it's the middle of winter. There's nothing like sitting out with a coffee to make you feel metropolitan. One for London lovers.

2-_TVC56Xel2ybuI2776bQ.text: Absolutely shocking prices! Granted, it does look like an authentic Italian coffee shop, but after getting past the nostalgia its just a shabby coffee shop. For a very small espresso shot (looks like half a shot), I feel ripped off paying £2. The only redeeming quality about the place is if you like Italian football, as they seem to show live matches on their big screen telly.

cdkycL63mSF_s4JEd330ng.text: GET A CANOLI! Holy Moly! Fricken delicious.  This is the coolest mom and pop italian restaurant.  Fool of heart and spirit.  They chat with you like your family.  If I hadn't just eaten, I would have bought a sandwich too.  This is such a great restaurant! Will come every time I'm in LA!

BRXNnV0fgAxdCNZ-27L7nA.text: On a recent visit to London, we visited this place to avoid the rain outside and we some time before our next meeting. With barstool seating along the wall and few seats in the back of the restaurant, the local match going on the TV, this turned out to be a perfect friendly place to watch the local people and enjoy read good London coffee and eta. It was all Italian décor and atmosphere in the middle of Soho. Server and staff were very friendly singing away to melodious tunes in between servings, great atmosphere and place to spend half an hour or so. Prices were not cheap but quality was good. Orth a second visit to try.

MztvSr6vwPcu2_c7tW1Ryg.text: Super friendly and honest service, everyone is just so nice, strikes up conversation, and takes your order swiftly at the counter. To date, the best tasting and strongest espresso I've ever had, and they needn't waste time or energy on "latte art" because their drinks stand alone. Caps will run about £3 and macchiatos about £2.80, but totally worth it because you really only need one, where you would need two at any other coffeehouse. They also sell their adorable cups and saucers with their storefront and Soho Frith Street address on them for about £7. Returning here always feels like I never left. Definitely a place that will stick in mind for many years to come.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Cakes
Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Delicious
Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Counter food

QC8r_38seZnxYsihK8oEOA.text: Aww, these guys have a genuine 1950's hand steam gaggia and turn out the best cappuccino. It takes 30 seconds from ordering to drinking. The guys are cool if you know what I mean but you feel like you are in a movie and everything is perfect. The panini's are easily missed but order a ham mozzarella and salad and know heaven on earth.Or just sit and watch the world go by. Great after night on the town but gets really busy after midnight.

CSDw7Lls1lfXisZArkvG5w.text: Absolute assholes. Avoid if you are a foreigner planning on paying by credit card. They think nothing of ripping you off and smirk while they do it. Bunch of wankers that shouldn't be in business. Avoid if you value honest service. Also, basically only has inadequate place to sit.

vooYhqhJDQo4CkTLlCoz0w.text: Bar Italia is always sold as bit of an institution. An authentic Italian oasis in the heart of soho - and I've always been told such good things about it.Ordered a coffee and lasagne, the coffee came and was really good. I could understand the praise....then 35 minutes later the lasagne arrived. We nearly left on two occasions because we had places to be, but were reassured it was coming, it was coming... and then two arrived. When the bill came we had to get this amended, as whilst they took one away, they still tried to charge for both. The staff just didn't seem to know what was going on.The Lasagne itself was okay, but for £10 expensive as it was pretty small and came without any side salad. More like a snack than something filling.I'm not sure I'll return, it was nice to be able to sit outside in Soho, and whilst the coffee was good, it was very cramped seating and I'm not sure I like the change in price for coffee depending on what time of day it is - this just seems a useless fuss.

FPFTkpx_IAqu70i61ACNyw.text: I've been introduced to what I think is a gem in the heart of Soho. Get ready to be transported to a little cafe in Italy. This place has been running for decades, family run through three generations! My friend used to come here as a baby with her folks and they still remember her. The coffee is excellent and the cannolis are to die for! It's open til 5am I think every night?? And reopens for breakfast at 7am. The staff are awesome, super friendly and efficient. A little on the pricey side (£13 something for two coffees and two cannolis) but worth it. If you ever find yourself roaming around soho at ridiculous o'oclock, you know you'll be welcome at Bar Italia, smash a cannoli or pizza slice, have a cuppa and a banter with the staff or the interesting characters that loiter. Ace.

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom

QIPDOc_c6NGV7CxOMrrBvQ.text: Went here as it was recommended on Antony Bourdain's Layover show. Very disappointing experience. Unnecessarily high-strung and rude operator behind the counter, who charged me more than menu price on my drinks and pastry order. To top it off, the cappuccino I ordered was awful. I'm a coffee enthusiast, who has frequented top coffee houses in North America and Europe. This was terrible, as the milk was heated to too high a temperature, making it undrinkable and killing any taste. Terrible experience, and the lowest review I have given any coffee shop.

byDhPZN3bWvS6QG4dqGFRw.text: Horrible.  Racist.  Should be fired.   This place should either shut down or get rid of its manager

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom

WBPkg_a7Iblts01gP9PmGA.text: Terrible service, rude man behind the bar, terrible coffee and they charge what they feel like - £7.50 for two coffees. We felt so intimidated that we didn't even want to dispute the charge. Would never give this place business again.

sgJuOZWbQnR5yOrejZfPZg.text: Small and delightful :) Nestled in the buzzy neighbourhood of SoHo,  it's a charming little cafe that serves great coffee and sweet cakes. I had my usual soya latte and red velvet cake,  both were wonderful and to perfection. My favourite time to come here is just after lunch,  to miss the crowds,  so I can sit back and watch the people wizz past. I don't think I've been here with anyone else before,  which is a great summary of this place. So,  if you want a sweet afternoon snack to be washed down with a caffeine infused beverage while enjoying some human watching,  this is your place :)

EhmWZ8sMTN9KWMgT_rVcdw.text: I was following in Anthony Bourdain's footsteps and I was only here for a coffee. Seriously, it was really good coffee. Cash only, sip it slowly, and people watch outside in this hidden gem.

2JJeRX85_PZDsCsMV845ig.text: When you seek a place to hang with your friends in Soho but require none of the dramas that goes along with raving such as jealousy, sown wild oats and half truths; Bar Italia offers a lively but wholesome experience, serving food and coffee and even glasses of milk.This is a renowned establishment in Soho and definitely worth checking out.

9HDsdeO6PCY0CvFzcCxFpg.text: I simply love Bar Italia. It's one if these London institutions that one simply has to try out. In short: it's an Italian coffee bar that's open 24 hours. It's not necessarily cozy in there with plush sofas and plenty of seating à la Starbucks. No, there's a counter with a giant espresso machine, a shelf displaying all kinds of snacks (think Portuguese custards, pannini sandwiches etc) and behind the counter there's a small army of Italian baristas (the non-hipster and genuine kind) who will serve you up your espresso drink in mere seconds. (This is also not a place where you should ask for complicated coffee concoctions à la Starbucks - keep it simple and real.)Given that this is not a place to linger, I typically come here for a quick espresso before heading on to a next destination - whether it be the National Gallery, a musical or a bar nearby. In the summer though, you might be lucky and snatch one of the prime seats outside. That's actually quite fun, as you can watch and comment on the diverse Soho crowd parading by...

hhJDL4web9uooqkQkI9Klw.text: Everywhere I turned, I kept hearing that the best coffee in all of London was here. Perhaps, and this can happen, there was just too much hype. To make matters worse, it was a very rainy moment in the day and I was fairly soaked, but I tried to keep my head and spirits held high (... I used to work at Disney World, what can I say?).The charming gent over the counter was all smiles and attentive, and I instantly felt better, rain be damned. I ordered an Americano and an espresso (for my bf). He loved his, so I let my cool a bit and took a sip. Weirdly, just then, the hair on chest stood on end ... even in a downpour. It was strong, is my basic point here. Not bad, just reeeeeeeeeeeally effing strong, okay? So, if you like strong coffee, you're in luck. The place is also open 24 hours, so I'm all for that schedule. We went back the next evening for a post-pub piece of cake (chocolate), and it was great and filling - and again, with only mediocre service, which I can let slide as they must deal with a lot of slurring drunks at that hour. Additionally, they seem to love Rocky Marciano here (my third cousin, no kidding), based on the decorations, so I can't be that hard on them. Or can I?

photos.caption: Photo of Bar Italia - London, United Kingdom. Rocky!

RRfzCCXCiR-qeJnu-dwCEg.text: I was told this place has some of the best coffee in London and that the breakfast is decent.  I made my way, via the Tube, then bus, the a short walk; finding it buried among other coffee shops and homes (far away from tourist spots).  It was the only place with customers and I found myself a seat outside between a few locals reading the paper and sipping their espresso.  I gave each of them a node and proceeded to find my way through the menu.  I landed on cafe latte (biggest one possible, I was TIRED) and the usual English breakfast (egg, sausage, 'bacon' and lots of toast).  I got my coffee in the largest clear tall glass; I wasn't sure if this was a joke against the bloody American.  It was strong and exactly what I needed!  For whatever reason, things always seem better while on vacation and paying 3.20£ for coffee!  Breakfast arrived shortly after (and after 10 minutes of second hand smoke).  The bacon wasn't as crispy as I like, but I think that might not be a British thing.  Not a bad breakfast for 5.50£.  You get to chat with the locals, watch people move their mattress through a second story window (ok...maybe not during your experience) and practice a little Italian.  You've got to stop here during your visit to London!!!

v-8bK1fobcmwqoCRzNjsAw.text: Perched near a corner of Frith St in Soho this is one of Anthony Bourdain's favourite places to go sit with a coffee (outside ideally) and watch London life go by. Which is good enough for me. And it does a damn good coffee at that.

9mJX2QH4aRaFw6OcHLouPQ.text: Coffee is like any 'spresso from any small cafe or (dare I say it) highway service centre in Italy. Difference is, you don't have to stand and drink!Fits perfectly into its Soho surroundings. Perfectly located for grabbing a pick me up while exploring.

7TGgUoAlCJ5QVJZZK43Spg.text: Pretty good panini. Their cannoli was delicious and I would definitely recommend it. The service was ok. Their credit card machine wasn't working but then hey said it was fixed. Then when it wad time to pay they said it was broken again. It was frustrating but we ended up working it out where the machine suddenly worked again.

N2hlYXdyPgq5Hsrtby5vdQ.text: This place hasn't changed since it first opened way back went. It is an amazing, traditional Italian coffee shop. All the staff are Italian and all the food they serve is traditional Italian. They do hot food as well as cakes and sweet treats. They make proper good Italian coffees, the espressos are so good. The cannoli are delicious, even the staff devour them! There are seats outside to watch the world go by but the best thing to do is grab a seat at the long espresso bar inside and watch the interactions of the staff and step back in time and imagine you are in Naples. The coffee and cakes are expensive but totally worth it.
